channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Airline Passenger With Ebola Is Under Treatment in Dallas
item.description: The man, who took a commercial flight from Liberia, is said to be the first traveler to have brought the virus to the United States on a passenger plane.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY

item.title: Ireland’s Tax Deals for Apple Prompt Warning From European Commission
item.description: The commission laid out its preliminary case over Apple’s taxes in Ireland, and it told the country it may order it to collect huge amounts of back taxes.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union's departing commissioner for competition.

item.title: European Nations Try to Stop Citizens From Joining Radicals in Iraq and Syria
item.description: Rising numbers have joined the Islamic State and other groups, prompting fears of domestic terrorism when the fighters return home.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Afghanistan and U.S. Sign Bilateral Security Agreement
item.description: The agreement, long delayed, allows 9,800 American and about 2,000 NATO troops to remain in Afghanistan after the international combat mission formally ends on Dec. 31.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Ambassador James B. Cunningham, left, and the new Afghan national security adviser, Hanif Atmar, after signing the security pact.

item.title: E.U. Inquiry Into Fiat Tax Deal Could Reverberate
item.description: Rivals say Jean-Claude Juncker, incoming president of the European Commission, helped turn Luxembourg into a tax haven.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, Luxembourg's former prime minister, is the incoming president of the European Commission.

item.title: Kurdish and Iraqi Forces Widen Offensive Against ISIS in Northern Iraq
item.description: Kurdish pesh merga fighters and Iraqi security forces began efforts to drive out the Islamic State from several parts of northern Iraq, including near the Syria border.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga fighters during a clash with Islamic State militants on Tuesday in the town of Daquq, south of Kirkuk.

item.title: Catalan Leaders Suspend Campaign for Independence Vote
item.description: The Catalan government said it would appeal an order by Spain’s Constitutional Court to suspend vote preparations, and insisted its secession plans were not over.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Open Source: Indian Anchor’s Scuffle in New York Draws Supporters and Critics
item.description: Indian journalists rallied Monday in support of a television host who was harassed by supporters of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Spanish Premier Insists Vote on Catalan Independence Will Not Happen
item.description: A decree signed by Catalonia’s leader authorizing a secession vote prompted a terse response from Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who said such a vote would be unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The Voice of a Hong Kong Student Protester
item.description: A look at the fears and motivations driving the anti-Beijing protests in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Jonah M. Kessel and Mona El-Naggar

item.title: Eurozone’s Drop in Inflation Carries More Fears of Another Recession
item.description: With inflation dipping to 0.3 percent and unemployment remaining at 11.5 percent, the E.U. received more unwelcome news before the central bank meets.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: A Conspicuous Absence on List of Top Baby Names
item.description: Israel’s population authority left Muhammad off the annual Top 10 list of baby names, even though it was No. 1, setting off a discussion about the status of the Arab minority.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Lens Blog: Japanese Swordsman With a Camera
item.description: Whether on Japan’s street or shores, Issei Suda takes pictures like a swordsman, with light swiftly slicing the scene.
item.category: Issei Suda: Life of a Flower.
item.dc:creator: By RENA SILVERMAN
item.media:credit: Issei Suda, Courtesy of Miyako Yoshinaga Gallery

item.title: In Creating ‘Martyrs’ Day,’ China Promotes a Vision of the Past
item.description: As Beijing’s tensions with neighbors rise, analysts see Martyrs’ Day as an effort by the Communist Party to be seen as a guardian against invaders.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: A worker set up a red carpet on Monday at the Monument to the People's Heroes in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Going to Comic Lengths to Stifle Foreign Coverage in Xinjiang
item.description: A television program from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation started out as an exploration into the grievances of Uighurs, but it turned into a look at the restrictions on the foreign news media.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Toxic Gases Delay Rescue on Volcano in Japan
item.description: High levels of poisonous gases near the peak of Mount Ontake led to a suspension of rescue operations after eight more bodies were recovered.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched on Monday for people missing near a mountain lodge on Mount Ontake in central Japan.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Clean and Polite, but a Protest Nonetheless
item.description: The crowds on the streets of Hong Kong maintain fastidious attention to hygiene and good manners as they rally for democracy.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters set up a first aid station on Tuesday in Hong Kong. Participants said the movement's attention to hygiene, good manners and trash sorting as well as its self-organized medical teams helped send a message of determination.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Umbrellas for Hong Kong?
item.description: During heavy censorship in mainland Chinese media of the Hong Kong democracy demonstrations, some images of umbrellas circulating online took on a special significance.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A metal barricade near the Hong Kong government headquarters was festooned with protesters' umbrellas on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Jiang Zemin, Former President, Makes Rare Appearance
item.description: Jiang Zemin, a former president and Communist Party chief who has often been rumored to be in poor health or even dead, is seen as still wielding influence in China.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping (front row, fourth from left) with Jiang Zemin to his left at a concert in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Leader Calls for Protests to End ‘Immediately’
item.description: Protest leaders responded with defiance Tuesday to Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying’s demand, threatening to occupy government buildings.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Leung Chun-ying, Hong Kong’s chief executive, at a news conference in January.

item.title: No Casualties After South Korean Tourist Boat Runs Aground
item.description: All 109 people on board were rescued, but the accident, the first notable ferry mishap since a ferry disaster in April, drew attention in the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Martyrs’ Day Ceremony, Solemnity and Goose-Stepping
item.description: Led by President Xi Jinping and the other six members of the Politburo Standing Committee, the 15-minute event was meant to draw attention to those who sacrificed for China’s freedom from foreign aggression.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Honor guards carry baskets of flowers as Chinese leaders led by President Xi Jinping mark Martyrs' Day on Tuesday at the Monument to the People's Heroes in Tiananmen Square, Beijing.

item.title: United Nations General Assembly: Netanyahu Links Hamas With ISIS, and Equates ISIS With Iran
item.description: The prime minister of Israel called Hamas and the group known as the Islamic State “branches of the same poisonous tree,” and Iran, he said, is the most dangerous country in the world.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: “Iran’s nuclear weapons capability must be fully dismantled,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the General Assembly.

item.title: Nicolae Corneanu, Bishop and Police Informer, Dies at 90
item.description: Mr. Corneanu acknowledged that he had been recruited by the Securitate, confirming suspicions that senior clerics had been closely tied to the regime of the Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Many Missteps in Assessment of ISIS Threat
item.description: The question of how officials failed to anticipate the rise of ISIS resonates inside and outside the Obama administration.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An image posted on the Islamic State’s website in January showing militants having moved from Syria into northern Iraq.
